headline.main: A Tasty Education In Indian Cuisine

docs.abstract: Stephanie Lyness reviews Thali restaurant in New Haven, Conn; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THALI is an innovative new restaurant in New Haven whose chef, Prasad Chirnomula, is determined to change the way we think about Indian food. Dishes come from all over India. They are unusual, exciting, and so varied that I am never bored with eating there. The atmosphere, a mix of traditional and contemporary, is more upscale than many of the Indian restaurants I've been to. In the entryway is an exquisite display of roses floating in free-standing copper vessels. Inside, tableware is chic and contemporary. The service is gracious and careful, with an eye toward educating the clientele.

headline.main: Indian Cuisine From a Diverse Menu

docs.abstract: Patricia Brooks reviews Malabar restaurant in Norwalk, Conn; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: FOR those who enjoy the well-seasoned foods of India, Malabar deserves an enthusiastic welcome. Although its storefront space is limited (serving about 30 people), Malabar, with its warm décor (vibrant orange and pale lime walls, a mural of a peaceful palm-fringed lagoon) and cordial staff helped dispel the winter blues from the moment we entered -- even before we took a single bite.
docs.snippet: Malabar's name, from the coast of southwest India, suggests that South Indian food is the restaurant's strength....

headline.main: Reassuming a First Love: Italian Cuisine

docs.abstract: Joanne Starkey reviews Giorgio, Italian restaurant in Roslyn, Long Island; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE lovely 140-year-old Italianate mansion at 1441 Old Northern Boulevard in Roslyn village is Italian once more. The last restaurant at this location was the Corral Steakhouse. It was part of a tidal wave of red-meat emporiums that recently swept the Island. But this one lasted less than a year. The owner, who also runs Giorgio Ristorante in Hampton Bays, decided to follow his heart rather than culinary trends and go back to his first love, Italian food. Earlier this fall, when the Hamptons restaurant closed for the season, its chef, manager and service staff made the westward trek to Roslyn to open this new Giorgio.

headline.main: The Cuisine Makes a Royal Statement

docs.abstract: Joanne Starkey reviews Louis XVI restaurant in Patchogue; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: ''LET them eat cake'' and foie gras, caviar, venison, lobster, even a dessert called the Marie Antoinette doll. The opening of the Louis XVI restaurant in Patchogue signals a return to elegant dining. Long Islanders who want more from a meal out than a bowl of pasta at a casual cafe have reason to rejoice. The imposing newcomer boasts a broad brick terrace that stretches to the edge of the Great South Bay. The shimmering water views, visible from every table, draw all eyes. They get a lot of competition, though, from the sparkling chandeliers, massive floral bouquets, marble foyer, fluted columns and 18th century-style paintings. Members of the regime ancien would feel right at home here, and so, too, will modern-day Long Islanders.

headline.main: Parcells Rumors Hotter Than Bayou Cuisine

docs.abstract: Article discusses numerous rumors surrounding future of New England Patriots coach Bill Parcells as he prepares team for Super Bowl (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The Patriots' future is taking on the trappings of their off-center past today as the Super Bowl-bound team found itself embroiled in an increasingly contentious dispute involving Coach Bill Parcells, his agent and the club's owner. The gist of the conflict is whether Parcells is completely free after Sunday's game with the Packers to look for a job someplace else, or whether the owner, Robert K. Kraft, has an option on his coach for next year, too, or can at least demand compensation from another team if Parcells leaves.

headline.main: CUISINE OF THAILAND: NEXT UP FOR STARDOM

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: BEFORE the sun is up in Bangkok, small flames flicker all over the city streets, marking the portable kitchens that dot the landscape and provide Bangkok residents with a never-ending supply of snacks.

headline.main: NEWEST FRENCH CUISINE SIMPLER THAN NOUVELLE

byline.original: By PATRICIA WELLS , Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: If the period from the early 1970's to early 80's celebrated the flourishing of nouvelle cuisine in France, the remaining years of the decade may go down as an era of equilibrium. More than ever the French are paying greater attention at table to health, as a tempered nouvelle cuisine becomes modern cuisine - a style defined most simply as light, creative and sophisticated, with roots in both classical and robustly regional French cooking. Neither chefs nor diners are going to do without garlicky frog's legs, lusty confit or homey pot-au-feu, but in France's finer Recipes are on page C8. restaurants, at least, diners are finding more fish and vegetables on the menu and they are drinking better but less, and when rich, luxurious cream and butter sauces apppear they are likely to be served with the main dish, not on it. Horizons have also broadened beyond the French borders, and pasta, vibrant spices, even nontraditional mozzarella are finding a spot on many menus.

headline.main: by Mimi Sheraton; A Viennese nouvelle cuisine.

docs.lead_paragraph: ALTHOUGH it seems quite natural that a negative review can damage a restaurant, it may be surprising to learn that a rave sometimes does a kind of damage all its own. Whether because of greed or inexperience, a restaurateur who gets a three-star or four-star rating, may pack the house beyond the capacities and temperaments of its kitchen and dining-room staff. The inevitable result of such action is poor food and rude or careless service, and a spate of justified complaints. It is gratifying, therefore, to discover that Vienna '79, which received a three-star rating last March, not only has been able to cope with success, but also has improved to the point where it well deserves a four-star rating. This despite the fact that the original chef left early in the fall to be replaced by the former sous-chef, Thomas Ferlesch, who is 24 years old. Full credit for this success belongs to Peter Grunauer, the proprietor, a dedicated cook and student of cuisine. Were he not, a change of chefs could turn this into a brand new restaurant. But Mr. Grunauer's consistent standards and knowledge of the cuisine has bridged the gap between staff changes, and his almost constant presence has kept cooks and waiters working smoothly and professionally.
